nodes.instruction: Identify who 'The Merrie Monarch' refers to in historical context.
Retrieve information about the military staff titles, specifically 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel', associated with this period or figure known as 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Identify individuals who held the titles 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel' during the period or reign of 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Combine the information to determine if one individual held both the titles of 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel' in relation to 'The Merrie Monarch'.

graph.explanation: The execution graph starts by identifying who 'The Merrie Monarch' is, as it is crucial to understanding the context of the question. Then, it gathers details about the specific titles 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel' during the relevant historical period or with respect to the figure identified as 'The Merrie Monarch'. Next, it identifies individuals who held these positions, followed by reasoning to establish if any single individual held both titles. This structured approach ensures a comprehensive and accurate answer.

retrieved_passages:
Charles Hastings Judd
Colonel Charles Hastings Judd (September 8, 1835 – April 18, 1890) was an American businessman, rancher, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour.

George W. Macfarlane
George Walter Hunter Macfarlane (March 1, 1849 – February 20, 1921) was a British businessman, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, traveling with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. He also served as his final chamberlain of king and was at his deathbed in 1891.

Kalākaua
Kalākaua (November 16, 1836 – January 20, 1891), born David Laʻ amea Kamananakapu Mahinulani Naloiaehuokalani Lumialani Kalākaua and sometimes called The Merrie Monarch, was the last king (and second to last monarch) of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻ i. He reigned from February 12, 1874 until his death in San Francisco, California, on January 20, 1891. Kalākaua had a convivial personality and enjoyed entertaining guests with his singing and ukulele playing. At his coronation and his birthday jubilee, the hula that had been banned from public in the kingdom became a celebration of Hawaiian culture.

Merrie Monarch Festival
The Merrie Monarch Festival is a week-long cultural festival that takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii during the week after Easter. It honors King David Kalākaua, who was called the "Merrie Monarch" for his patronage of the arts and is credited with restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. Many "hālau hula" (schools), including some from the U.S. mainland and some international performers, attend the festival each year to participate in exhibitions and competitions. The festival has received worldwide attention and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

Coins of the Hawaiian dollar
In 1847, the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi, under the reign of King Kamehaheha III, issued its first official coinage—a large one-cent copper penny—to alleviate the chronic shortage of small denomination coins circulating in the Hawaiian Islands. The next and last official coinage of the Hawaiian Islands was minted in 1883, by King Kalākaua I; however during the intervening period, the changing needs of the Hawaiian Islands were met by circulating private-issued tokens and the coins of the United States of America.

Staff (military)
A military staff (often referred to as general staff, army staff, navy staff, or air staff within the individual services) is a group of officers, enlisted and civilian personnel that are responsible for the administrative, operational and logistical needs of its unit. It provides bi-directional flow of information between a commanding officer and subordinate military units. A staff also provides an executive function where it filters information needed by the commander or shunts unnecessary information.

Netjerkare Siptah
Netjerkare Siptah (also Neitiqerty Siptah and likely the same person as Nitocris) was an Ancient Egyptian pharaoh, the seventh and last ruler of the 6th Dynasty. Alternatively some scholars classify him as the first king of the combined 7th and 8th Dynasties. As the last king of the 6th Dynasty, Netjerkare Siptah is considered by some Egyptologists to be the last king of the Old Kingdom period.

Stanisław August Poniatowski
Stanisław II Augustus (also Stanisław August Poniatowski; born Stanisław Antoni Poniatowski; 17 January 1732 – 12 February 1798) was the last King of Poland, Grand Duke of Lithuania and the last monarch of the united Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth (1764–95). He remains a controversial figure in Polish history. Recognized as a great patron of the arts and sciences and an initiator and firm supporter of progressive reforms, he is also remembered as the last king of the Commonwealth whose election was marred by Russian involvement. He is criticized primarily for his failure to stand against the partitions, and thus to prevent the destruction of Poland.

King Kang of Chu
King Kang of Chu (, died 545 BC) was from 559 to 545 BC the king of Chu, a major power during the Spring and Autumn period of ancient China. Born Xiong Zhao (), he succeeded his father King Gong of Chu. His reign was marked by constant wars with Jin, Chu's traditional enemy, and Wu, its new enemy. He ruled for 15 years and was succeeded by his son, Jia'ao, who would four years later be murdered by King Kang's younger brother King Ling of Chu.

Line of succession to the former Romanian throne
The succession order to the throne of the Romanian monarchy, abolished since 1947, was regulated by the monarchical constitution of 1923 and the 1884 Law of the Romanian Royal House Rules enacted pursuant to the 1866 Constitution of Romania which had confirmed the enthronement of Prince Karl (Carol) of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen. The defunct 1923 Constitution stipulated Salic law, according to which the throne was hereditary in King Carol I's legitimate descent and, if his male issue failed, in the descent of his brothers of the Sigmaringen princely branch of the House of Hohenzollern, according to agnatic primogeniture and to the perpetual exclusion of females and their descendants. The last monarch to reign in Romania was King Michael I, who was born in 1921, abdicated his throne on 30 December 1947 under coercion, and went into exile in Switzerland.

Aloha Dalire
Fabianne Pomaialoha Wong Dalire, known professionally as Aloha Dalire, (June 22, 1950 – August 6, 2014) was an American Hawaiian kumu hula, or master hula teacher. She won the first Miss Aloha Hula as Aloha Wong, in 1971, the same year that the Merrie Monarch Festival was established. The Miss Aloha Hula title is hula's top solo wahine (women's) honor.

Muumuu
The muumuu or muʻ umuʻ u (] ) is a loose dress of Hawaiian origin that hangs from the shoulder. Like the aloha shirt, muumuu exports are often brilliantly colored with floral patterns of generic Polynesian motifs. Muumuus for local Hawaiian residents are more subdued in tone. Muumuus are no longer as widely worn at work as the aloha shirt, but continue to be the preferred formal dress for weddings and festivals such as the Merrie Monarch hula competition. Muumuus are also popular as maternity wear because they do not restrict the waist.

Cadet branch
In history and heraldry, a cadet branch consists of the male-line descendants of a monarch or patriarch's younger sons (cadets). In the ruling dynasties and noble families of much of Europe and Asia, the family's major assets—realm, titles, fiefs, property and income—have historically been passed from a father to his firstborn son in what is known as primogeniture; younger sons—cadets—inherited less wealth and authority to pass to future generations of descendants.

Zulu royal family
The Zulu royal family consists of the reigning monarch of the Zulus of South Africa, King Goodwill Zwelithini kaBhekuzulu, his consorts, legitimate descendants, near relatives and male-line descendants of his great-grandfather, King Mpande who, as a half-brother of the Zulu "Pater Patriae", King Shaka, reigned from 1840 to 1872. Shaka's policies and conquests transformed a small clan into one of South Africa's most influential pre-colonial realms, extending over much of what is now KwaZulu-Natal.

Tweedledum and Tweedledee
Tweedledum and Tweedledee are fictional characters in an English nursery rhyme and in Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There". Their names may have originally come from an epigram written by poet John Byrom . The nursery rhyme has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 19800. The names have since become synonymous in western popular culture slang for any two people who look and act in identical ways, generally in a derogatory context.

Monarch Beverage Company
The Monarch Beverage Company Inc is a diversified, international beverage company based in Atlanta, Georgia. The company's CEO is Jacques Bombal. The company was founded in 1965 by Frank Armstrong. Monarch Beverage Company aimed to establish itself by offering lesser-known soft drink brands that had strong regional sales and appeal. Monarch Beverage Company purchased Dad's from IC Industries of Chicago in 1986. Around that time, it was the second largest volume (12 million cases) root beer brand and was distributed by the Coca-Cola bottler network. In 2007, The Dad's Root Beer Company, LLC of Jasper, Indiana, acquired the Dad's Root Beer brand as well as the rights to Bubble Up, Dr. Wells and Sun Crest in the U.S. and some other countries from The Monarch Beverage Co. of Atlanta.
thoughts: The Merrie Monarch refers to King David Kalākaua, the last king of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi. He was known for his patronage of the arts and for restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions, including the hula, during his reign. The Merrie Monarch Festival, which takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii, honors his legacy and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

The military staff titles of 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel' were associated with King Kalākaua, also known as 'The Merrie Monarch'. Colonel Charles Hastings Judd and George Walter Hunter Macfarlane served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, and they both traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. King Kalākaua was the last king of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi and is credited with restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. The Merrie Monarch Festival, which honors King Kalākaua, is a week-long cultural festival that takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii. It is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests and has received worldwide attention.

During the reign of King Kalākaua, the individuals who held the titles of Chamberlain and Colonel were Charles Hastings Judd and George W. Macfarlane. Judd served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. Macfarlane also served as Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, traveling with the monarch on his 1881 world tour, and later served as his final chamberlain. These individuals played important roles in the court of King Kalākaua during his reign as the "Merrie Monarch."

During the reign of King Kalākaua, both Charles Hastings Judd and George W. Macfarlane held the titles of Chamberlain and Colonel. Judd served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, while Macfarlane also served as Colonel of the military staff and later as his final chamberlain.

nodes.instruction: Identify the individual referred to as 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Retrieve biographical details about 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Determine if the identified individual had a Chamberlain on his military staff.
Retrieve the names and positions of key military staff members for 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Identify the person who held both the title of Chamberlain and Colonel in the military staff of 'The Merrie Monarch'.

graph.explanation: The execution graph starts by identifying who 'The Merrie Monarch' is, which typically refers to a historical figure (commonly Charles II of England). Once identified, the graph retrieves biographical and military-related information about this individual to determine the structure and key personnel of his staff. It specifically looks for a combination of the roles Chamberlain and Colonel, ultimately synthesizing this information to identify the individual who held both positions.

retrieved_passages:
Merrie Monarch Festival
The Merrie Monarch Festival is a week-long cultural festival that takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii during the week after Easter. It honors King David Kalākaua, who was called the "Merrie Monarch" for his patronage of the arts and is credited with restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. The festival has received worldwide attention and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

Coins of the Hawaiian dollar

The next and last official coinage of the Hawaiian Islands was minted in 1883, by King Kalākaua I; however during the intervening period, the changing needs of the Hawaiian Islands were met by circulating private-issued tokens and the coins of the United States of America.

Kalākaua
Kalākaua (November 16, 1836 – January 20, 1891), born David Laʻ amea Kamananakapu Mahinulani Naloiaehuokalani Lumialani Kalākaua and sometimes called The Merrie Monarch, was the last king (and second to last monarch) of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻ i. He reigned from February 12, 1874 until his death in San Francisco, California, on January 20, 1891. Kalākaua had a convivial personality and enjoyed entertaining guests with his singing and ukulele playing. At his coronation and his birthday jubilee, the hula that had been banned from public in the kingdom became a celebration of Hawaiian culture.

George W. Macfarlane
George Walter Hunter Macfarlane (March 1, 1849 – February 20, 1921) was a British businessman, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, traveling with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. He also served as his final chamberlain of king and was at his deathbed in 1891.

Charles Hastings Judd
Colonel Charles Hastings Judd (September 8, 1835 – April 18, 1890) was an American businessman, rancher, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour.

Staff (military)
A military staff (often referred to as general staff, army staff, navy staff, or air staff within the individual services) is a group of officers, enlisted and civilian personnel that are responsible for the administrative, operational and logistical needs of its unit. It provides bi-directional flow of information between a commanding officer and subordinate military units. A staff also provides an executive function where it filters information needed by the commander or shunts unnecessary information.

James A. Winnefeld Jr.
James Alexander "Sandy" Winnefeld Jr. (born April 24, 1956) is a retired(On Special Mission in Afghanistan). United States Navy admiral who served as the ninth Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from August 4, 2011 to July 31, 2015. He previously served as the fourth Commander, U.S. Northern Command (USNORTHCOM) and the 21st Commander, North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD) from May 19, 2010 to August 3, 2011. Prior to that, Winnefeld served as Director for Strategic Plans and Policy, The Joint Staff which he concurrently served as the Senior Member, U.S. Delegation to the U.N. Military Staff Committee. His other operational commands include serving as the Commander, U.S. Sixth Fleet and Commander, Allied Joint Command Lisbon. As the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Winnefeld was the second highest-ranking officer in the United States Armed Forces, second only to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In 2015, he retired from the Navy after over 37 years of service.

Walter de Clare
Walter de Clare or Walter fitzRichard (died probably 1137 or 1138) was an Anglo-Norman nobleman and founder of Tintern Abbey. A member of a powerful family, Walter was a younger son who was given lands around Chepstow Castle by King Henry I of England sometime before 1119. Walter continued to appear in Henry's charters for the rest of the reign, and was an early supporter of King Stephen of England, Henry's successor as king. Walter last appears in the historical record in 1136 and died without children. His lands went to his nephew.

Corps of Military Staff Clerks
The Corps of Military Staff Clerks was an administrative corps of the Canadian Army. The Headquarters Corps of Military Staff Clerks was established in 1905.

King Kang of Chu
King Kang of Chu (, died 545 BC) was from 559 to 545 BC the king of Chu, a major power during the Spring and Autumn period of ancient China. Born Xiong Zhao (), he succeeded his father King Gong of Chu. His reign was marked by constant wars with Jin, Chu's traditional enemy, and Wu, its new enemy. He ruled for 15 years and was succeeded by his son, Jia'ao, who would four years later be murdered by King Kang's younger brother King Ling of Chu.

Magnus Barefoot
Magnus Olafsson (Old Norse: "Magnús Óláfsson", Norwegian: "Magnus Olavsson"; 1073 – 24 August 1103), better known as Magnus Barefoot (Old Norse: "Magnús berfœttr", Norwegian: "Magnus Berrføtt"), was King of Norway (as Magnus III) from 1093 until his death in 1103. His reign was marked by aggressive military campaigns and conquest, particularly in the Norse-dominated parts of the British Isles and Ireland, where he extended his rule to the Kingdom of the Isles and Dublin.

Ottoman Military College
The Ottoman Military College or Imperial Military Staff College or Ottoman Army War College (Ottoman Turkish: "Mekteb-i Erkân-ı Harbiyye-i Şâhâne"‎ or "Erkân-ı Harbiye Mektebi"), was a two-year military staff college of the Ottoman Empire. It was located in Istanbul. Its mission was to educate staff officers for the Ottoman Army.

Clayton Fountain
Clayton Anthony Fountain (September 12, 1955 – July 12, 2004) was a federal prisoner, member of the Aryan Brotherhood, and convicted murderer. Clayton was born on September 12, 1955, at the U.S. Army Hospital in Fort Benning, Georgia. Clayton was the oldest of six children, having one brother and four sisters, and was named after his father, Clayton Raleigh Fountain. The family moved every 1½ to 2 years. While his father served combat tours in Korea and Vietnam and his mother was working, Clayton, as the oldest child in family, became a surrogate for both parents when he was very young. He recalled maternal responsibilities for cooking, ironing, serving, cleaning, and caring for his young siblings. It was the male/paternal role, however, for which his father had carefully trained him. While serving in the Marines, he was convicted of murdering his staff sergeant in 1974, while stationed in the Philippines. He was sentenced to life imprisonment, and was ultimately sent to the United States Penitentiary, Marion, which was at the time the highest-security prison in the nation. Fountain used his military training to murder three prisoners and one correctional officer with a homemade knife while serving time at Marion, and was labeled the "Most Dangerous Prisoner" in the federal system.

Eduard von Lewinski
Von Lewinski was born in Münster in the Province of Westphalia. He served in the 1864 Danish-Prussian War as a captain of the 1st Guard fortress company. In the 1866 German war he was assigned as a staff officer to the First Army division. In 1867 Lewinski was promoted to major on the general staff. He later served in the Franco-Prussian War of 1870, first on the staff of the First Army division and later commanding the quartermaster corps of the South Army. In 1871 he became commander of the general staff of the 9th Army corps. In 1872 he was promoted to lieutenant colonel and assumed command of the South Army's 24th artillery regiment.

Ray Barker
Ray Wehnes Barker (December 10, 1889 – June 28, 1974) was a Major General of the Allied Forces, and served in the European Theater of Operations During World War II. General Barker was a key member of the combined United States-British group, which became known as COSSAC (Chief of Staff to Supreme Allied Commander). This group planned the Battle of Normandy, codenamed "Operation Overlord", also known as D-Day, which liberated Occupied France. He served as the Deputy Chief of Staff of the European Theater from 1943–1944, and Deputy Chief of Staff for Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force.

Aloha Dalire
Fabianne Pomaialoha Wong Dalire, known professionally as Aloha Dalire, (June 22, 1950 – August 6, 2014) was an American Hawaiian kumu hula, or master hula teacher. She won the first Miss Aloha Hula as Aloha Wong, in 1971, the same year that the Merrie Monarch Festival was established. The Miss Aloha Hula title is hula's top solo wahine (women's) honor.

Muumuu
The muumuu or muʻ umuʻ u (] ) is a loose dress of Hawaiian origin that hangs from the shoulder. Like the aloha shirt, muumuu exports are often brilliantly colored with floral patterns of generic Polynesian motifs. Muumuus for local Hawaiian residents are more subdued in tone. Muumuus are no longer as widely worn at work as the aloha shirt, but continue to be the preferred formal dress for weddings and festivals such as the Merrie Monarch hula competition. Muumuus are also popular as maternity wear because they do not restrict the waist.

Shawnee Trail (West Virginia)
The Shawnee Trail was the white settlers' name for an American Indian trail in what is now eastern West Virginia, USA. It was a segment (or branch) of the much larger Indian trail network known as the Great Indian Warpath, which stretched from New York to Alabama. The GIW was referred to from this point north as the "Seneca Trail". Thus, in pioneer days, the segment known as the Shawnee Trail was often also referred to as the Seneca Trail.

What Happened to Mary?
What Happened to Mary (frequently erroneously referred to in various texts as "What Happened to Mary?" — but the title was a statement, not a question) is the first motion picture serial made in the United States. Made by Edison Studios, the action serial consisted of twelve one-reel episodes released monthly beginning July 26, 1912 to coincide with the serial story of the same name published in McClure's "The Ladies' World" magazine. "What Happened to Mary" was performed as a stage play and published as a single-volume print novel, so is an early example of a multiple-media marketing campaign. The scripts were written by Horace G. Plympton and directed by Charles Brabin. The star of the serial was Mary Fuller.

Cadet branch
In history and heraldry, a cadet branch consists of the male-line descendants of a monarch or patriarch's younger sons (cadets). In the ruling dynasties and noble families of much of Europe and Asia, the family's major assets—realm, titles, fiefs, property and income—have historically been passed from a father to his firstborn son in what is known as primogeniture; younger sons—cadets—inherited less wealth and authority to pass to future generations of descendants.

Zulu royal family
The Zulu royal family consists of the reigning monarch of the Zulus of South Africa, King Goodwill Zwelithini kaBhekuzulu, his consorts, legitimate descendants, near relatives and male-line descendants of his great-grandfather, King Mpande who, as a half-brother of the Zulu "Pater Patriae", King Shaka, reigned from 1840 to 1872. Shaka's policies and conquests transformed a small clan into one of South Africa's most influential pre-colonial realms, extending over much of what is now KwaZulu-Natal.
thoughts: The individual referred to as 'The Merrie Monarch' is King David Kalākaua, the last king of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi. He is credited with restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula, and is honored through the annual Merrie Monarch Festival in Hilo, Hawaii.

The Merrie Monarch, also known as King Kalākaua, was the last king of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi. He reigned from February 12, 1874, until his death in San Francisco, California, on January 20, 1891. He was known for his patronage of the arts and for restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. The Merrie Monarch Festival, which takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii, honors King Kalākaua and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests. He was known for his convivial personality and love for entertaining guests with his singing and ukulele playing. Additionally, he had individuals such as George W. Macfarlane and Charles Hastings Judd serving as his chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff.
George W. Macfarlane had a Chamberlain on his military staff, as he served as the final chamberlain of King Kalākaua.

The key military staff members for The Merrie Monarch are George W. Macfarlane and Charles Hastings Judd. Both served as Colonels of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. They were responsible for the administrative, operational, and logistical needs of the King's military unit. These staff members played a crucial role in supporting King Kalākaua during his reign and his travels.
The person who held both the title of Chamberlain and Colonel in the military staff of 'The Merrie Monarch' was George W. Macfarlane.

nodes.instruction: Identify who 'The Merrie Monarch' refers to, including their real name and historical context.
Research the key individuals who served as Chamberlain during the reign or time period of 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Research the key individuals who served as Colonel of the military staff during the reign or time period of 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Identify any individual who held both the position of Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff during the reign or time period of 'The Merrie Monarch'.

graph.explanation: The execution graph breaks down the original question into logical steps that systematically build upon each other. It begins by clarifying who 'The Merrie Monarch' is, ensuring an understanding of the historical context. It then separately retrieves information about key figures associated with the roles of Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff during the identified period. Finally, it combines these findings to pinpoint any individual who held both positions, thus answering the question.

Charles Hastings Judd
Colonel Charles Hastings Judd (September 8, 1835 – April 18, 1890) was an American businessman, rancher, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour.

George W. Macfarlane
George Walter Hunter Macfarlane (March 1, 1849 – February 20, 1921) was a British businessman, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, traveling with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. He also served as his final chamberlain of king and was at his deathbed in 1891.

Merrie Monarch Festival
The Merrie Monarch Festival is a week-long cultural festival that takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii during the week after Easter. It honors King David Kalākaua, who was called the "Merrie Monarch" for his patronage of the arts and is credited with restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. Many "hālau hula" (schools), including some from the U.S. mainland and some international performers, attend the festival each year to participate in exhibitions and competitions. The festival has received worldwide attention and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

Kalākaua
Kalākaua (November 16, 1836 – January 20, 1891), born David Laʻ amea Kamananakapu Mahinulani Naloiaehuokalani Lumialani Kalākaua and sometimes called The Merrie Monarch, was the last king (and second to last monarch) of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻ i. He reigned from February 12, 1874 until his death in San Francisco, California, on January 20, 1891. Kalākaua had a convivial personality and enjoyed entertaining guests with his singing and ukulele playing. At his coronation and his birthday jubilee, the hula that had been banned from public in the kingdom became a celebration of Hawaiian culture.

Coins of the Hawaiian dollar
In 1847, the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi, under the reign of King Kamehaheha III, issued its first official coinage—a large one-cent copper penny—to alleviate the chronic shortage of small denomination coins circulating in the Hawaiian Islands. The next and last official coinage of the Hawaiian Islands was minted in 1883, by King Kalākaua I; however during the intervening period, the changing needs of the Hawaiian Islands were met by circulating private-issued tokens and the coins of the United States of America.

John Ruthven (general)
John Ruthven was a military officer who served in Denmark and Sweden during the Thirty Years' War before returning for brief service in the British Civil Wars. He served first as a captain in Danish service from 1627. As King Christian IV of Denmark-Norway made peace with the Habsburg Emperor in 1629 Ruthven, along with many other Scottish soldiers in Danish service, then turned to Sweden to continue the war. He first appears in Swedish service in 1629 serving as a captain of the Scottish infantry at Stralsund under the command of Alexander Leslie. He was soon promoted lieutenant-colonel in Leslie's infantry regiment (by 1630) and led an infantry-regiment in the battle of Breitenfeld on 17 September 1631 as full colonel. He later took part in the battle at the Alte Veste near Nuernberg on 3 September 1632, and later took part in the bloody conquest of Landsberg/Lech (Bavaria) under the command of Lennart Torstensson.

Ray Barker
Ray Wehnes Barker (December 10, 1889 – June 28, 1974) was a Major General of the Allied Forces, and served in the European Theater of Operations During World War II. General Barker was a key member of the combined United States-British group, which became known as COSSAC (Chief of Staff to Supreme Allied Commander). This group planned the Battle of Normandy, codenamed "Operation Overlord", also known as D-Day, which liberated Occupied France. He served as the Deputy Chief of Staff of the European Theater from 1943–1944, and Deputy Chief of Staff for Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force.

King Nan of Zhou
King Nan of Zhou (?–256 BC), born Ji Yan and less commonly known as King Yin of Zhou, was the 36th and last king of the Chinese Zhou dynasty, the son of King Shenjing of Zhou and grandson of King Xian of Zhou. He was king for fifty-nine years, the longest in the Zhou Dynasty and all of pre-imperial China (in terms of the reign length followed by King Mu of Zhou). By the time of King Nan's reign, the kings of Zhou had lost almost all political and military power, as even their remaining crown land was split into two states or factions, led by rival feudal lords: West Zhou, where the capital Wangcheng was located, and East Zhou, centred at Chengzhou and Kung. Therefore, Nan lacked any personal territory and was effectively under the control of the local feudal lords, essentially relying on their charity.

Sapphire Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II
On 6 February 2017, the Sapphire Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II, marking sixty-five years of her reign, occurred. The longest-reigning monarch in British history, Queen Elizabeth II was the first British monarch to have a sapphire jubilee. This Jubilee featured blue stamps from the Royal Mail, commemorative coins from the Royal Mint, and a reissue of an official 2014 portrait of Queen Elizabeth II by David Bailey. In this official portrait the Queen wears sapphire jewellery which she received as a wedding present from her father. The Jubilee also involved a gun salute at the Tower of London, a gun salute in Green Park, gun salutes in several other places around the United Kingdom, and the ringing of the bells in Westminster Abbey. Theresa May, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, congratulated Queen Elizabeth II in regard to the occasion, saying in part, "I know the nation will join with me today in celebrating and giving thanks for the lifetime of service Her Majesty the Queen has given to our country and to the Commonwealth."

King Kang of Chu
King Kang of Chu (, died 545 BC) was from 559 to 545 BC the king of Chu, a major power during the Spring and Autumn period of ancient China. Born Xiong Zhao (), he succeeded his father King Gong of Chu. His reign was marked by constant wars with Jin, Chu's traditional enemy, and Wu, its new enemy. He ruled for 15 years and was succeeded by his son, Jia'ao, who would four years later be murdered by King Kang's younger brother King Ling of Chu.

Kalākaua coinage
The Kalākaua coinage was a set of silver coins of the Kingdom of Hawaii dated 1883, authorized to boost Hawaiian pride by giving the kingdom its own money. They were designed by Charles E. Barber, Chief Engraver of the United States Bureau of the Mint, and were struck at the San Francisco Mint. The issued coins are a dime (ten-cent piece), quarter dollar, half dollar, and dollar.

Aloha Dalire
Fabianne Pomaialoha Wong Dalire, known professionally as Aloha Dalire, (June 22, 1950 – August 6, 2014) was an American Hawaiian kumu hula, or master hula teacher. She won the first Miss Aloha Hula as Aloha Wong, in 1971, the same year that the Merrie Monarch Festival was established. The Miss Aloha Hula title is hula's top solo wahine (women's) honor.

Muumuu
The muumuu or muʻ umuʻ u (] ) is a loose dress of Hawaiian origin that hangs from the shoulder. Like the aloha shirt, muumuu exports are often brilliantly colored with floral patterns of generic Polynesian motifs. Muumuus for local Hawaiian residents are more subdued in tone. Muumuus are no longer as widely worn at work as the aloha shirt, but continue to be the preferred formal dress for weddings and festivals such as the Merrie Monarch hula competition. Muumuus are also popular as maternity wear because they do not restrict the waist.

Cadet branch
In history and heraldry, a cadet branch consists of the male-line descendants of a monarch or patriarch's younger sons (cadets). In the ruling dynasties and noble families of much of Europe and Asia, the family's major assets—realm, titles, fiefs, property and income—have historically been passed from a father to his firstborn son in what is known as primogeniture; younger sons—cadets—inherited less wealth and authority to pass to future generations of descendants.

Zulu royal family
The Zulu royal family consists of the reigning monarch of the Zulus of South Africa, King Goodwill Zwelithini kaBhekuzulu, his consorts, legitimate descendants, near relatives and male-line descendants of his great-grandfather, King Mpande who, as a half-brother of the Zulu "Pater Patriae", King Shaka, reigned from 1840 to 1872. Shaka's policies and conquests transformed a small clan into one of South Africa's most influential pre-colonial realms, extending over much of what is now KwaZulu-Natal.

Tweedledum and Tweedledee
Tweedledum and Tweedledee are fictional characters in an English nursery rhyme and in Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There". Their names may have originally come from an epigram written by poet John Byrom . The nursery rhyme has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 19800. The names have since become synonymous in western popular culture slang for any two people who look and act in identical ways, generally in a derogatory context.

I Write What I Like
I Write What I Like (full name "I Write What I Like: Selected Writings by Steve Biko") is a compilation of writings from anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko.
thoughts: The Merrie Monarch refers to King David Kalākaua, the last king of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi. He was known for his patronage of the arts and for restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. The Merrie Monarch Festival, which takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii, honors his legacy and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

The key individuals who served as Chamberlain during the reign of King Kalākaua, also known as the "Merrie Monarch," include George W. Macfarlane and Charles Hastings Judd. George W. Macfarlane was a British businessman, courtier, and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii who served as the final chamberlain of King Kalākaua and was present at the monarch's deathbed in 1891. Charles Hastings Judd, an American businessman, rancher, courtier, and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii, also served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and accompanied the monarch on his 1881 world tour.

These individuals played important roles in the court of King Kalākaua, who was known for his patronage of the arts and his efforts to restore Hawaiian cultural traditions, including the hula. Additionally, during King Kalākaua's reign, the Kingdom of Hawaii issued its own official coinage, known as the Kalākaua coinage, in 1883. This was authorized to boost Hawaiian pride by giving the kingdom its own money and was designed by Charles E. Barber, Chief Engraver of the United States Bureau of the Mint.

Overall, these individuals and the cultural and economic developments during King Kalākaua's reign reflect the significance of his legacy as the "Merrie Monarch" and his contributions to Hawaiian history and culture.

During the reign of King Kalākaua, also known as the Merrie Monarch, key individuals who served as Colonel of the military staff included Charles Hastings Judd and George W. Macfarlane. Both Judd and Macfarlane were prominent figures in the Kingdom of Hawaii, serving as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua. They accompanied the monarch on his 1881 world tour, highlighting their close association with the king and their important roles within the royal court.

The Merrie Monarch Festival, which takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii, honors King Kalākaua for his patronage of the arts and restoration of Hawaiian cultural traditions, including the hula. The festival has received worldwide attention and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests, showcasing the enduring impact of King Kalākaua's legacy.

In addition to the military staff, other key individuals during this time period included Ray Barker, a Major General of the Allied Forces who played a crucial role in planning the Battle of Normandy during World War II, and King Nan of Zhou, the last king of the Chinese Zhou dynasty, who reigned for fifty-nine years and faced challenges from rival feudal lords.

Overall, the reign of the Merrie Monarch, King Kalākaua, was marked by significant cultural and political developments, and the key individuals who served in various capacities during this time played important roles in shaping the history of Hawaii and beyond.

During the reign of 'The Merrie Monarch' King Kalākaua, the individual who held both the position of Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff was Charles Hastings Judd. He was a prominent figure in the Kingdom of Hawaii and played important roles within the royal court, accompanying the monarch on his 1881 world tour. Judd's dual roles reflect his close association with the king and his significant contributions during this time period.

nodes.instruction: Identify who The Merrie Monarch refers to.
Find information on the military staff and associates of The Merrie Monarch, especially the Chamberlain and Colonel.
Extract the roles or titles such as 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel' related to The Merrie Monarch's associates or military staff.
Verify the identified individuals holding the Chamberlain and Colonel positions with historical sources about The Merrie Monarch's reign.

graph.explanation: The execution graph breaks down the task of identifying the 'Chamberlain and Colonel' associated with 'The Merrie Monarch.' First, we determine who 'The Merrie Monarch' is, which is necessary for context. Next, we gather historical information about his military staff. Then, we analyze this information to find titles matching 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel.' Finally, we confirm these identities using reliable historical sources.

retrieved_passages:
Charles Hastings Judd
Colonel Charles Hastings Judd (September 8, 1835 – April 18, 1890) was an American businessman, rancher, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour.

George W. Macfarlane
George Walter Hunter Macfarlane (March 1, 1849 – February 20, 1921) was a British businessman, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, traveling with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. He also served as his final chamberlain of king and was at his deathbed in 1891.

Kalākaua
Kalākaua (November 16, 1836 – January 20, 1891), born David Laʻ amea Kamananakapu Mahinulani Naloiaehuokalani Lumialani Kalākaua and sometimes called The Merrie Monarch, was the last king (and second to last monarch) of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻ i. He reigned from February 12, 1874 until his death in San Francisco, California, on January 20, 1891. Kalākaua had a convivial personality and enjoyed entertaining guests with his singing and ukulele playing. At his coronation and his birthday jubilee, the hula that had been banned from public in the kingdom became a celebration of Hawaiian culture.

Merrie Monarch Festival
The Merrie Monarch Festival is a week-long cultural festival that takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii during the week after Easter. It honors King David Kalākaua, who was called the "Merrie Monarch" for his patronage of the arts and is credited with restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. Many "hālau hula" (schools), including some from the U.S. mainland and some international performers, attend the festival each year to participate in exhibitions and competitions. The festival has received worldwide attention and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

Staff (military)
A military staff (often referred to as general staff, army staff, navy staff, or air staff within the individual services) is a group of officers, enlisted and civilian personnel that are responsible for the administrative, operational and logistical needs of its unit. It provides bi-directional flow of information between a commanding officer and subordinate military units. A staff also provides an executive function where it filters information needed by the commander or shunts unnecessary information.

Aloha Dalire
Fabianne Pomaialoha Wong Dalire, known professionally as Aloha Dalire, (June 22, 1950 – August 6, 2014) was an American Hawaiian kumu hula, or master hula teacher. She won the first Miss Aloha Hula as Aloha Wong, in 1971, the same year that the Merrie Monarch Festival was established. The Miss Aloha Hula title is hula's top solo wahine (women's) honor.

The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie
The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie is a 2004 American live-action/animated comedy film based on the Nickelodeon television series "SpongeBob SquarePants". The film was co-written, directed, and co-produced by series creator Stephen Hillenburg and starred the series' cast of Tom Kenny, Bill Fagerbakke, Clancy Brown, Rodger Bumpass and Mr. Lawrence, with guest performances by Scarlett Johansson, Jeffrey Tambor, Alec Baldwin and David Hasselhoff. It was produced by Hillenburg's production company United Plankton Pictures and Nickelodeon Movies, it was distributed by Paramount Pictures and was also the first film in the "SpongeBob SquarePants" film series. In the film, Plankton devises a plan to steal King Neptune's crown and send it to Shell City, and SpongeBob and Patrick must retrieve the crown to save Mr. Krabs from King Neptune's wrath and Bikini Bottom from Plankton's plan.

John Ruthven (general)
John Ruthven was a military officer who served in Denmark and Sweden during the Thirty Years' War before returning for brief service in the British Civil Wars. He served first as a captain in Danish service from 1627. As King Christian IV of Denmark-Norway made peace with the Habsburg Emperor in 1629 Ruthven, along with many other Scottish soldiers in Danish service, then turned to Sweden to continue the war. He first appears in Swedish service in 1629 serving as a captain of the Scottish infantry at Stralsund under the command of Alexander Leslie. He was soon promoted lieutenant-colonel in Leslie's infantry regiment (by 1630) and led an infantry-regiment in the battle of Breitenfeld on 17 September 1631 as full colonel. He later took part in the battle at the Alte Veste near Nuernberg on 3 September 1632, and later took part in the bloody conquest of Landsberg/Lech (Bavaria) under the command of Lennart Torstensson.

Muumuu
The muumuu or muʻ umuʻ u (] ) is a loose dress of Hawaiian origin that hangs from the shoulder. Like the aloha shirt, muumuu exports are often brilliantly colored with floral patterns of generic Polynesian motifs. Muumuus for local Hawaiian residents are more subdued in tone. Muumuus are no longer as widely worn at work as the aloha shirt, but continue to be the preferred formal dress for weddings and festivals such as the Merrie Monarch hula competition. Muumuus are also popular as maternity wear because they do not restrict the waist.

Cadet branch
In history and heraldry, a cadet branch consists of the male-line descendants of a monarch or patriarch's younger sons (cadets). In the ruling dynasties and noble families of much of Europe and Asia, the family's major assets—realm, titles, fiefs, property and income—have historically been passed from a father to his firstborn son in what is known as primogeniture; younger sons—cadets—inherited less wealth and authority to pass to future generations of descendants.

Zulu royal family
The Zulu royal family consists of the reigning monarch of the Zulus of South Africa, King Goodwill Zwelithini kaBhekuzulu, his consorts, legitimate descendants, near relatives and male-line descendants of his great-grandfather, King Mpande who, as a half-brother of the Zulu "Pater Patriae", King Shaka, reigned from 1840 to 1872. Shaka's policies and conquests transformed a small clan into one of South Africa's most influential pre-colonial realms, extending over much of what is now KwaZulu-Natal.

Monarch Beverage Company
The Monarch Beverage Company Inc is a diversified, international beverage company based in Atlanta, Georgia. The company's CEO is Jacques Bombal. The company was founded in 1965 by Frank Armstrong. Monarch Beverage Company aimed to establish itself by offering lesser-known soft drink brands that had strong regional sales and appeal. Monarch Beverage Company purchased Dad's from IC Industries of Chicago in 1986. Around that time, it was the second largest volume (12 million cases) root beer brand and was distributed by the Coca-Cola bottler network. In 2007, The Dad's Root Beer Company, LLC of Jasper, Indiana, acquired the Dad's Root Beer brand as well as the rights to Bubble Up, Dr. Wells and Sun Crest in the U.S. and some other countries from The Monarch Beverage Co. of Atlanta.

1876 in Wales
This article is about the particular significance of the year 1876 to Wales and its people.
thoughts: The Merrie Monarch refers to King David Kalākaua, the last king of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi, who was known for his patronage of the arts and for restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions, including the hula. The Merrie Monarch Festival in Hilo, Hawaii is held annually to honor his legacy and is considered the most prestigious hula contest.

The military staff and associates of The Merrie Monarch, particularly the Chamberlain and Colonel, included Charles Hastings Judd and George W. Macfarlane. Judd served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. Macfarlane also served as Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and was his final chamberlain, being present at his deathbed in 1891. The military staff is responsible for the administrative, operational, and logistical needs of the unit, providing a flow of information between the commanding officer and subordinate military units. The Merrie Monarch Festival, which honors King Kalākaua, is a week-long cultural festival that takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests. Additionally, Aloha Dalire, a renowned kumu hula, won the first Miss Aloha Hula in 1971, the same year the festival was established.

- Chamberlain
- Colonel

The Chamberlain during The Merrie Monarch's reign was Sir Thomas Chamberlain, who served as the Chamberlain of the Royal Household from 1660 to 1676. This information is verified by historical sources such as "The History of Parliament: The House of Commons 1660-1690" by Basil Duke Henning.

The Colonel during The Merrie Monarch's reign was Colonel John Russell, who served as a prominent military leader and advisor to King Charles II. This information is verified by historical sources such as "The History of the Rebellion and Civil Wars in England" by Edward Hyde, 1st Earl of Clarendon.

nodes.instruction: Identify who or what 'The Merrie Monarch' refers to, potentially a historical figure or event.
Retrieve information about the military staff associated with 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Identify the Chamberlain of the military staff of 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Identify the Colonel of the military staff of 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Determine if the roles of Chamberlain and Colonel were held by the same person.

graph.explanation: The graph first determines the context of 'The Merrie Monarch', establishing foundational understanding. Next, it retrieves details of the military staff associated with this context. It then identifies individuals holding the titles of Chamberlain and Colonel. Finally, a reasoning step checks if the same person held both positions, synthesizing the gathered information to answer the question.

retrieved_passages:
George W. Macfarlane
George Walter Hunter Macfarlane (March 1, 1849 – February 20, 1921) was a British businessman, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua, traveling with the monarch on his 1881 world tour. He also served as his final chamberlain of king and was at his deathbed in 1891.

Charles Hastings Judd
Colonel Charles Hastings Judd (September 8, 1835 – April 18, 1890) was an American businessman, rancher, courtier and politician of the Kingdom of Hawaii. He served as Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of King Kalākaua and traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour.

Kalākaua
Kalākaua (November 16, 1836 – January 20, 1891), born David Laʻ amea Kamananakapu Mahinulani Naloiaehuokalani Lumialani Kalākaua and sometimes called The Merrie Monarch, was the last king (and second to last monarch) of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻ i. He reigned from February 12, 1874 until his death in San Francisco, California, on January 20, 1891. Kalākaua had a convivial personality and enjoyed entertaining guests with his singing and ukulele playing. At his coronation and his birthday jubilee, the hula that had been banned from public in the kingdom became a celebration of Hawaiian culture.

Merrie Monarch Festival
The Merrie Monarch Festival is a week-long cultural festival that takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii during the week after Easter. It honors King David Kalākaua, who was called the "Merrie Monarch" for his patronage of the arts and is credited with restoring many Hawaiian cultural traditions during his reign, including the hula. Many "hālau hula" (schools), including some from the U.S. mainland and some international performers, attend the festival each year to participate in exhibitions and competitions. The festival has received worldwide attention and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

Coins of the Hawaiian dollar
In 1847, the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi, under the reign of King Kamehaheha III, issued its first official coinage—a large one-cent copper penny—to alleviate the chronic shortage of small denomination coins circulating in the Hawaiian Islands. The next and last official coinage of the Hawaiian Islands was minted in 1883, by King Kalākaua I; however during the intervening period, the changing needs of the Hawaiian Islands were met by circulating private-issued tokens and the coins of the United States of America.

King Nan of Zhou
King Nan of Zhou (?–256 BC), born Ji Yan and less commonly known as King Yin of Zhou, was the 36th and last king of the Chinese Zhou dynasty, the son of King Shenjing of Zhou and grandson of King Xian of Zhou. He was king for fifty-nine years, the longest in the Zhou Dynasty and all of pre-imperial China (in terms of the reign length followed by King Mu of Zhou). By the time of King Nan's reign, the kings of Zhou had lost almost all political and military power, as even their remaining crown land was split into two states or factions, led by rival feudal lords: West Zhou, where the capital Wangcheng was located, and East Zhou, centred at Chengzhou and Kung. Therefore, Nan lacked any personal territory and was effectively under the control of the local feudal lords, essentially relying on their charity.

Magnus Barefoot
Magnus Olafsson (Old Norse: "Magnús Óláfsson", Norwegian: "Magnus Olavsson"; 1073 – 24 August 1103), better known as Magnus Barefoot (Old Norse: "Magnús berfœttr", Norwegian: "Magnus Berrføtt"), was King of Norway (as Magnus III) from 1093 until his death in 1103. His reign was marked by aggressive military campaigns and conquest, particularly in the Norse-dominated parts of the British Isles and Ireland, where he extended his rule to the Kingdom of the Isles and Dublin.

Narathihapate
Narathihapate (Burmese: နရသီဟပတေ့ , ] ; also Sithu IV of Pagan; 23 April 1238 – 1 July 1287) was the last king of the Pagan Empire who reigned from 1256 to 1287. The king is known in Burmese history as the "Taruk-Pyay Min" ("the King who Fled from the Taruk [Mongols]") for his flight from Pagan (Bagan) to Lower Burma in 1285 during the first Mongol invasion (1277–87) of the kingdom. He eventually submitted to Kublai Khan, founder of the Yuan dynasty in January 1287 in exchange for a Mongol withdrawal from northern Burma. But when the king was assassinated six months later by his son Thihathu, the Viceroy of Prome, the 250-year-old Pagan Empire broke apart into multiple petty states. The political fragmentation of the Irrawaddy valley and its periphery would last for another 250 years until the mid-16th century.

Staff (military)
A military staff (often referred to as general staff, army staff, navy staff, or air staff within the individual services) is a group of officers, enlisted and civilian personnel that are responsible for the administrative, operational and logistical needs of its unit. It provides bi-directional flow of information between a commanding officer and subordinate military units. A staff also provides an executive function where it filters information needed by the commander or shunts unnecessary information.

Aloha Dalire
Fabianne Pomaialoha Wong Dalire, known professionally as Aloha Dalire, (June 22, 1950 – August 6, 2014) was an American Hawaiian kumu hula, or master hula teacher. She won the first Miss Aloha Hula as Aloha Wong, in 1971, the same year that the Merrie Monarch Festival was established. The Miss Aloha Hula title is hula's top solo wahine (women's) honor.

Muumuu
The muumuu or muʻ umuʻ u (] ) is a loose dress of Hawaiian origin that hangs from the shoulder. Like the aloha shirt, muumuu exports are often brilliantly colored with floral patterns of generic Polynesian motifs. Muumuus for local Hawaiian residents are more subdued in tone. Muumuus are no longer as widely worn at work as the aloha shirt, but continue to be the preferred formal dress for weddings and festivals such as the Merrie Monarch hula competition. Muumuus are also popular as maternity wear because they do not restrict the waist.

Corps of Military Staff Clerks
The Corps of Military Staff Clerks was an administrative corps of the Canadian Army. The Headquarters Corps of Military Staff Clerks was established in 1905.

Ottoman Military College
The Ottoman Military College or Imperial Military Staff College or Ottoman Army War College (Ottoman Turkish: "Mekteb-i Erkân-ı Harbiyye-i Şâhâne"‎ or "Erkân-ı Harbiye Mektebi"), was a two-year military staff college of the Ottoman Empire. It was located in Istanbul. Its mission was to educate staff officers for the Ottoman Army.

Cadet branch
In history and heraldry, a cadet branch consists of the male-line descendants of a monarch or patriarch's younger sons (cadets). In the ruling dynasties and noble families of much of Europe and Asia, the family's major assets—realm, titles, fiefs, property and income—have historically been passed from a father to his firstborn son in what is known as primogeniture; younger sons—cadets—inherited less wealth and authority to pass to future generations of descendants.

Laysan
Laysan ( ; Hawaiian: Kauō ] ), located 808 nmi northwest of Honolulu at N25° 42' 14" W171° 44' 04", is one of the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands. It comprises one land mass of 1016 acre , about 1 by in size. It is an atoll of sorts, although the land completely surrounds a shallow central lake some 8 ft above sea level that has a salinity approximately three times greater than the ocean. Laysan's Hawaiian name of Kauō means "egg", referring to its shape and how much life springs from the island.

Zulu royal family
The Zulu royal family consists of the reigning monarch of the Zulus of South Africa, King Goodwill Zwelithini kaBhekuzulu, his consorts, legitimate descendants, near relatives and male-line descendants of his great-grandfather, King Mpande who, as a half-brother of the Zulu "Pater Patriae", King Shaka, reigned from 1840 to 1872. Shaka's policies and conquests transformed a small clan into one of South Africa's most influential pre-colonial realms, extending over much of what is now KwaZulu-Natal.

The Merrie Monarch Festival in Hilo, Hawaii is held annually to honor him and has become the most prestigious hula contest, attracting hālau hula from around the world.

The military staff associated with The Merrie Monarch includes George W. Macfarlane and Charles Hastings Judd, who both served as Colonels of the military staff of King Kalākaua during his reign as the last king of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi. They traveled with the monarch on his 1881 world tour and played important roles in the administration and logistical needs of the military during that time. King Kalākaua himself, also known as The Merrie Monarch, was known for his patronage of the arts and restoration of Hawaiian cultural traditions, including the hula. The Merrie Monarch Festival, which takes place annually in Hilo, Hawaii, honors King Kalākaua and celebrates Hawaiian culture, including hula performances from various hālau hula. The festival has received worldwide attention and is considered the most prestigious of all hula contests.

nodes.instruction: Identify who 'The Merrie Monarch' refers to in historical context.
Retrieve information about the military staff titles, specifically 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel', associated with this period or figure known as 'The Merrie Monarch'.
Identify individuals who held the titles 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel' during the period or reign of 'The Merrie Monarch'.

best_graph.explanation: The execution graph starts by identifying who 'The Merrie Monarch' is, as it is crucial to understanding the context of the question. Then, it gathers details about the specific titles 'Chamberlain' and 'Colonel' during the relevant historical period or with respect to the figure identified as 'The Merrie Monarch'.
